text: <@U08C464NS|chris> has joined the channel
Hey man, how's it going? So what are your thoughts on the various ways this could make money?
sure, first of all by integrating payments into the protocol, i think this will open a lot more avenues for revenue that other social media apps
companies will not have to rely on advertising revenue (although that could still play a role)

basically, provide value-adds that people believe are worth money. for instance, people might be willing to pay to host their avatar. seems simple and silly, but it's possibly a source of revenue. maybe they have to pay every time they want to update their avatar.
of course, they can always have another company host it, possibly for free. but if one company makes it really easy and it shows up everywhere, people might be willing to pay.
another option is users might be willing to pay to download archival content
so like a more granular version of storj?
yes, i suppose. it's not about general data storage, but about very specific data that gets displayed in a specific way on the app
yeah
so people might pay a premium for that. more than just the cost of the data storage/transmission.
are you still thinking that "likes" or appreciation points will actually equate to tiny amounts of BTC?
maybe. i think the content will probably displayed for free (recent data in small amounts), but then users can "tip" or "buy" content
another possible source of revenue is that part of the tipped amount goes to the node they get it from
perhaps it goes through several relays... each one getting a cut. not really sure.
yeah that's what I initially thought it'd be
i prefer to make sure the user that produced the content gets all or most of the revenue.
yeah
very exciting exploring all these new ways of doing things :simple_smile:
however if the users find it palatable to support the companies that make the content easy to access, they might be willing to swallow a voluntary fee of 30% or something
voluntary, because they can always route around a company that charges too much
(sorry for newb questions). So would that mean it's fully distributed or federated?
the goal is NOT federated. anybody should be able to run a fully privileged node.
ok, that's good :simple_smile:
i think it will be analgous to bitcoin miners
at the start, anybody could mine ... but it eventually became a specialized industry. most people don't bother to mine anymore.
technically, anybody still can. bitcoin is properly decentralized at the protocol level.
but because some people are so good, they basically outcompeted the rest.
so that'd mean potentially DATT the company could become one of the players and be profitable that way?
yes that's the idea. the goal is to create a profitable business by being the first, largest, most reliable, best-branded node on the network
i call this The Satoshi Model - Satoshi is the richest bitcoiner because he was the first and most reliable miner

of course there are a lot of people helping to build this who may or may not be a part of my company ... so there might be more businesses from the start. that would probably be a good thing, because it would help to bootstrap the network.
yeah man, it'd still be open
I like it
how was the meeting in SF?
it was pretty awesome. 10 or so people were there. free food :simple_smile:
i spent a couple hours just talking with people there who haven't said much on slack
cool man :simple_smile:. I'm going to play with a few more ideas today. Specifically what the wallet balance view would look like
awesome! can't wait to see :simple_smile:
Cool. Thanks for answering the question mate. I'll probably be on later then. Peace!
ok see ya

^ thats  an attractive spreadsheet for investors. Obviously there's a lot of assumptions in there tough
<@U08BY8MGV>: yep i agree with <@U08FELGRX>, this shows the potential for the path for Monetization
that's really interesting. if an 'average node' can see $50m/year,  then the superior business model might be to remove the 1.25% cut and be the prime supporter of a major, reputable node
i think ryan talked about that last night, essentially leveraging first-mover advantage
The 1.25% cut is charged to the content creators by the Node (application). That's how the Node makes $50m per year
<@U07GDL0H5|ryanxcharles> pinned a message to this channel.
So devs have their coding to do, what can us non-devs work out? Business model? market analysis?
yo <@U08FELGRX> , business model, how the moderation works, how "tipping" "buying" "sponsoring" whatever works
got it

attachments.text: yo <@U08FELGRX> , business model, how the moderation works, how "tipping" "buying" "sponsoring" whatever works

text: <@U08FELGRX|dean> pinned a message to this channel.

From a semantics perspective is it better to 'gild' or 'tip' or both?
When you tip you don't expect anything in return, but if you 'sponsor' you may anticipate a possible return.
Should anyone be able to 'sponsor' a post or just the Author?
Should an OP linking to content be rewarded in the same way as an OP who's written a self post?
we might be running out of message limit on Slack, anyone knows how to Archive and retrieve the message, kind of export/import feature?
I thought Slack pruned old posts
the question of sponsorship is interesting. could become content bounties
I think it would be a good idea to divide the spreadsheet into full node and maybe smaller nodes which might not host full content.
Will create a separate sheet for this
<@U07GDL0H5>:  What are you referring to by "buying" in the comment earlier? Is it like the A2A in quora?
I would like to subdivide the commercials from a network perspective as the income the network makes will depend on that.

Also, I am still dithering about the concept of payment for commenting, and payment to content creator on receiving comments. If the network is truly decentralized with anonymity this would work very well. But, in real life users will get to know each other very quickly. Anyway, this is a question for later.

<@U08EZP01H>: I absolutely see this as a bounty. This is a bridge for mainstream publishers to dip their toes in DATT and see how the audience reacts, all the while no one is forced into seeing sponsored content, it's opt-in
thats huge for adoption too
It's hopefully a key differentiator too

<@U08DH3ESU>: I'm also not tied to a set fee for commenting, but at least something should be at stake. One of my ideas is to refund the amount to the commenter if they maintain >100 karma on their comment. Trolls will likely drop to 0 so they have wasted their money
With sponsorship we might lose the point on anonymity. But as long as anonymous comments are in place it is still fine.

<@U08ERPTQF> l don't have a problem with fee for commenting if it comes with the consent of the creator or it gets a certain number of up votes from people with a certain amount of karma. Something like the comment adds value  so it deserves an reward.
What control would the typical creator want to have over the comments on their post?
What you describe in your last sentence is akin to gilding comments that add to the discussion - I think anyone should be able to gild
<@U08CBD41G|delitzer> has joined the channel
Creator should not have control. But a comment acknowledged by the creator gets value attached. But we need to be careful about this.
Agree creator should not need to have control. But why restrict it to the creator in attaching value to a comment?
Not a restriction, but more weightage

Interesting, an author has a vested interest in having quality comments and discussion around their post, so their 'endorsement' of a comment could have more weighting - at the same time this does encourage a circle-jerk mentality if taken too far

text: most content creators would probably not reply to comments, especially if they're posting heavily on across multiple mediums, they wouldn't have time. They might reply to a select few.
<@U08FELGRX>: I'm just not sure that the creator will really know which mod is involved and which node, it depends on how distributed DATT is

text: i think as long as we maintain an emphasis on getting content creators paid for there work, then demand should go up from the simple, low barrier to entry
especially if we can get a good plan going for things like content bounties, 'tips' or even p2p subscriptions
I posted a spreadsheet with just the bounty/tip models to see what outcomes that may encourage

I think we can then layer other incentives on top for mods/collectives and nodes
subscriptions is an interesting avenue
so reddit makes $650,000 per MONTH just from reddit gold sales
thata a big market
nice!
<@U08FELGRX> where did u get that $ figure?
